(b) Typical structures and compositions of MXenes are characterized by a formula denoted as M n+1X n T x . In this formula, M represents an early transition metal, X can be either carbon (C) or nitrogen (N), and T x indicates the surface terminations. The value of n can range from 1 to 4. The M sites within MXenes can be occupied by one, two, or more transition metal atoms, leading to the formation of either solid solutions or ordered structures. The ordered structures of MXenes encompass in-plane ordered structures, known as i-MXenes, such as (Mo2/3Y1/3)2CT x . They also include in-plane vacancy structures, exemplified by Mo2/3CT x . Additionally, out-of-plane ordered structures, referred to as o-MXenes, are characterized by one or two layers of MII transition metal being sandwiched between layers of MI transition metal. Examples of o-MXenes include Cr2TiC2T x and Mo2Ti2C3T x , Reproduced with permission from Ref. [209]. Copyright 2021, Wiley. Graphical abstract This review presents the HER of 2D MXENE-based materials in acidic, neutral, and alkaline environments, investigating electron transfer enhancement, strain-induced mechanisms, external atom doping, thinning layers, active site formation, and synergistic composites, along with diverse energy conversion applications. The increasing focus on electrocatalysis for sustainable hydrogen (H2) production has prompted significant interest in MXenes, a class of two-dimensional (2D) materials comprising metal carbides, carbonitrides, and nitrides. These materials exhibit intriguing chemical and physical properties, including excellent electrical conductivity and a large surface area, making them attractive candidates for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). This scientific review explores recent advancements in MXene-based electrocatalysts for HER kinetics. It discusses various compositions, functionalities, and explicit design principles while providing a comprehensive overview of synthesis methods, exceptional properties, and electro-catalytic approaches for H2 production via electrochemical reactions. Furthermore, challenges and future prospects in designing MXenes-based electrocatalysts with enhanced kinetics are highlighted, emphasizing the potential of incorporating different metals to expand the scope of electrochemical reactions. This review suggests possible efforts for developing advanced MXenes-based electrocatalysts, particularly for efficient H2 generation through electrochemical water-splitting reactions.. Keywords MXenes Electrocatalyst Water Splitting Hydrogen Generation Clean Energy 1 Introduction With the rising challenges of environmental pollution and energy scarcity, there is a growing focus on sustainable energy solutions, particularly in the field of hydrogen (H2) production technologies [1,2]. H2 offers numerous advantages, including its status as a clean fuel with zero pollution emissions and no greenhouse gas production. It possesses a high energy density of 142 kJ/g, which can be recycled, and is compatible with fuel cells and renewable energy sources [3,4]. Demand for H2 production has significantly increased over the years, surpassing the levels seen in 1978 by approximately threefold. This heightened demand is primarily driven by applications in ammonia production, steel manufacturing, oil refining, and various other industrial sectors [5]. In addition to being used in these sectors, H2 is now being explored as an alternative source to mitigate the annual emission of 830 million tons of carbon dioxide from coal and natural gas [6]. Therefore, developing and scaling up technologies to produce green hydrogen has become crucial. Fig. 1 illustrates the H2 demand based on a compilation of literature data, showcasing the continuous upward trajectory of global H2 production trends and future projections. The corresponding figure also highlights the current global market size of H2 in terms of USD billions, indicating investments and outputs aimed at fostering a more sustainable society [7]. There are various pathways to produce H2, each with differing carbon intensity levels and technological maturity. Currently, the majority of hydrogen is generated from fossil fuels via steam methane reforming or coal gasification, which emit significant greenhouse gas emissions [8–12]. The energy efficiency and environmental impact of H2 production depend on the specific method employed. Several approaches have been developed to reduce the costs associated with H2 production, including thermochemical water splitting, photobiological water splitting, and photoelectrochemical water splitting [13]. Among these methods, electrochemical water splitting through the electrocatalysis of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is an economically viable and environmentally friendly approach for producing renewable H2 fuel [14–16]. Since the adsorption/desorption of hydrogen is the base of HER, the interaction between hydrogen and active sites can meaningly influence the catalytic process. The electrocatalytic reactions involved in the HER require only two essential reagents: water and a carefully chosen electrocatalyst [17,18]. Noble metal-based electrocatalysts, such as platinum (Pt), ruthenium (Ru), and rhodium (Rh), have exhibited excellent performance and stability in HER [19–24]. However, their primary drawbacks are the high cost and limited availability of these precious metals. As a result, there has been a concerted effort to develop more cost-effective and sustainable electrocatalysts for HER, particularly those based on non-precious metals (NPM), to enhance the efficiency of H2 production [9]. Currently, various electrocatalytic materials have been developed, including carbides [25], nitrides [26], oxides [27], phosphides [28], sulfides [29], and even metal-free nanocarbon. However, two primary challenges persist in this field. First, there is a notable decrease in catalytic activity and an increase in the thickness of the active coating due to poor electrical conductivity. Second, these NPM-based materials exhibit lower stability in electrochemical reactions within aqueous electrolytes. In recent material advancements, two-dimensional (2D) materials like graphene [30], transition metal dichalcogenides (e.g., MoS2, MoSe2) [30], germanene [31], phosphorene [32], boron nitrides [33], silicenes [34], layered doubled oxides/hydroxides [35], and graphitic carbon nitride [36] have shown great promise as exceptional electrocatalysts owing to their controllable composition, atomically thin structure, and tailored properties. Among these 2D materials, MXenes have emerged as a notable class. MXenes are graphene-like 2D transition metal carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides with the general chemical formula M n +1X n T x . Here, M represents an early transition metal (e.g., Ti, V, Nb, Mo, and Zr), X represents carbon or nitrogen, and T x represents surface functional groups such as –O, –OH, –F, or –Se. The value of n can be 1, 2, 3, or 4. In [MX] n M arrangement, the M layers cover the X layers [37]. The MXenes (Ti3C2T x ) were first discovered by Gogotsi's group in 2011 through the exfoliation of Ti3AlC2 MAX phase [38]. These materials gained significant attention due to their exceptional characteristics, such as an intrinsic layered structure, chemical stability, high carrier mobility, superior electrical conductivity, and large surface areas [39]. As a result, research on MXenes-based catalysts for the HER has steadily increased over the years [38]. Fig. 1(b and c) provides visual evidence based on the growing number of studies conducted and reported in the literature. Initially, MXenes were synthesized with only one or two transition metals such as Ti2CO2 [40], Nb4C3T x [41], Mo2CO2 [42], Ti3C2T x nanofibers (NFs) [43], M2NO2 [44], Mo2TiC2O2 [45], Ti2CT x [46], Mo2CT z [47], Mo2Nb2C3T x [48], Ti3C2 [49], Ti3C2O2 [50], Cr2CT x [51], TiVCT x [30], etc. However, in recent years, the variety of MXenes has significantly expanded to include high-entropy 2D carbides with four transition metals, such as TiVCrMoC3 and TiVNbMoC3 [25]. Fig. 1(d) demonstrates that 2D MXenes can be synthesized by selectively treating M n +1AX n precursors with etchants like concentrated hydrogen fluoride (HF) aqueous solution or a solution of lithium fluoride (LiF) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) [4,16]. During etching, the stronger M–X bonds within the MAX structure remain largely intact, while the weaker M–A bonds are cleaved. This delamination process results in the exfoliation and isolation of 2D MXene nanosheets, typically a few atomic layers thick (∼1 nm) with lateral dimensions of several microns [6]. MXenes exhibit excellent flexibility, laminar structures, 2D morphology, adjustable structure, good hydrophilicity, and exceptional metallic conductivity (∼10,000 S/cm). Specifically, for electrochemical energy storage as well as conversion systems, the electrical conductivity of MXenes has a crucial role. The conductivity of MXene can be finely adjusted by manipulating the termination group (T x ). Specifically, the presence of –OH and –F terminations generally leads to higher conductivity than –O or –OH/–F mixed terminations. This tunability enhances the biosensor's selectivity and affinity, thereby improving its capacity to detect specific biomolecules [52]. These properties enable the effective combination of MXenes with other functional materials, producing MXene-composited materials that exhibit excellent properties [1,5]. As a result, MXene-based nanosheets and nanocomposites have gained significant attention for their potential applications in energy conversion devices and energy storage as electrocatalysts and electrode materials [38]. The current review provides a detailed analysis and critical assessment of the recent progress in synthesizing and applying MXenes as electrocatalysts for the HER. The review begins by providing a concise overview of the various techniques employed in MXene synthesis and highlights their inherent properties. Subsequently, a meticulous evaluation of the diverse applications of MXenes as highly efficient catalysts for HER is presented. The review emphasizes the significance of structure engineering, surface modification, compositional optimization, and doping as emerging strategies to enhance the performance of MXenes in HER. The overall thematic idea of this review study can be seen in Scheme 1 . Additionally, the review addresses the existing challenges associated with these techniques and offers insightful recommendations for their future advancement. 2 Hydrogen discovery and production The hydrogen discovery and evaluation timeline, as shown in Fig. 2 , spans several centuries, beginning with the first observations in the late 16th century and progressing through numerous scientific advancements. In 1671, Robert Boyle identified hydrogen gas, which he called “inflammable air”, while studying the reactions of metals with acids. Antoine Lavoisier further investigated hydrogen in the late 18th century, recognizing it as a distinct element and naming it “hydrogen” based on its composition of water-forming substances. In 1868, Sir William Grove developed the first practical H2 fuel cell, establishing its potential as a clean energy source. In the early 20th century, advancements in industrial processes allowed for large-scale hydrogen production. The applications of hydrogen evaluation gained momentum in the late 20th and early 21st centuries. Furthermore, hydrogen is explored as a means for energy storage and grid balancing, complementing intermittent renewable energy sources. In recent years, research and development have focused on overcoming challenges associated with hydrogen production, storage, and distribution, aiming to enhance efficiency and reduce costs. 2.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction As a fundamental electrochemical process, the reduction in proton (H+) concentration within an aqueous solution leads to hydrogen gas (H2) generation via the HER. The HER holds significant importance in various fields, including electrocatalysis, waste management, energy storage, and energy conversion [56–58]. Protons are converted to H2 at the surface of catalyst in the HER. The general response is expressed using Eq. (1). (1) 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 The process consists of two distinct sequential steps involving the transfer of a single electron during each step. During the initial step, a proton undergoes a transformation, forming a hydrogen atom (H). Subsequently, in the second step, two H undergo a combination reaction, creating H2 [59]. The evaluation of catalyst performance for the HER often relies on the determination of overpotential, which represents the potential required to drive the reaction at a specific current density. The overpotential serves as a critical parameter in assessing the efficacy of a catalyst in promoting the HER process [60–63]. Since less energy is needed to drive the reaction, a catalyst with a lower overpotential will be more effective. The HER activity of a catalyst can be influenced by various factors, including its surface area, shape, and chemical composition [64,65]. Furthermore, the effectiveness of a catalyst is influenced by its composition and surface characteristics [66]. The HER reaction holds significant importance in energy conversion and storage, as it offers a viable means to produce hydrogen gas, a sustainable and environmentally friendly fuel source [67,68]. The overall HER behaviour in various mediums (acidic, neutral, and basic) can be seen in Fig. 3 . 2.1.1 Acidic medium It is commonly acknowledged that the HER is a multi-step electrochemical phenomenon that happens on the cathode surface [74]. The following reactions show how the multi-step electrochemical system functions under acidic conditions [75,76]. Within an acidic environment, the Volmer reaction (Eq. (2)) initiates the discharge of hydronium ions and the subsequent formation of hydrogen intermediates (M–H). Heyrovsky electrochemical stage (Eq. (3)) and/or the chemical Tafel step (Eq. (4)) are then necessary for H2 synthesis [77]. Fig. 3(a) illustrates the HER mechanism in an acidic medium. In contrast to acidic or alkaline conditions, where HER occurs rapidly, proton availability and kinetics often hinder the reaction in neutral media [77,79]. Researchers have concentrated on finding novel catalyst materials to enhance the reaction because of the sluggish kinetics of HER in neutral environments [80]. These catalysts are classified into two types: molecular catalysts and solid-state catalysts. Complexes comprising transition metals and ligands that may coordinate with protons and aid the reduction of H+ to H2 are often used as molecular catalysts [81,82]. For example, metal oxides, sulfides, and phosphides are solid-state catalysts that may catalyse the process by providing active sites for proton reduction [83,84]. The optimization of catalyst materials for HER in neutral media is a major field of study since the capacity to create H2 effectively from neutral water sources has significant implications for sustainable energy production and storage [85,86]. Fig. 3(d) depicts the geometric model MoP/MoS2, with HER free energy diagram (Fig. 3e), and the energy of H2O adsorption on the interfaces of MoP/MoS2 heterojunctions, MoP, and MoS2, given in Fig. 3(f) [71]. The widely recognized HER mechanism in alkaline and neutral liquids consists of three basic reaction stages [87,88]. (5) H2O + e− ⇄ Hads + OH− Volmer step (6) Hads + H2O + e− ⇄ H2 + OH− Heyrovsky step (7) 2Hads ⇄ H2 Tafel step In the first Volmer step, water molecules are broken in half, and hydrogen is adsorbed along a separate site of the particle surface. After that, hydrogen is produced via an electrochemical (Heyrovsky step 5) or chemical (Tafel step 6) method. According to some reported research outcomes, the Volmer process is performed through a comparable Heyrovsky but also Tafel step in the HER mechanism at moderate overpotentials, whereas the Tafel step is minimal, and the Volmer-Heyrovsky method is used to carry out the reaction at high overpotentials [89,90]. Recent research for HER in neutral medium can also be seen through given linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of Pt-Ti3C2T x and Pt/C [72] (Fig. 3g). The corresponding catalyst (Pt-Ti3C2T x ) demonstrated robust electrochemical activity for HER with a 67.8 mV overpotential value, which is very close to commercial Pt/C electrocatalyst (64.2 mV) [72]. 2.1.3 Basic medium Although several effective electrocatalysts toward HER in an acidic media have also been found, they do not all have the same activity level. However, the operation of acid-based PEM cells always leads to sublimation of electrolytes or a stronger acidic fog, which corrodes electrolytic cell and taints the generated H2 [91]. Alkaline electrolytes, on the other hand, have the benefit of producing less fumes under large temperature working circumstances because of their smaller pressure of vapor, which aids in the creation of pure H2 gas [92]. The HER mechanism in basic/alkaline medium can be seen in Fig. 3(h) [69]. Moreover, by limiting corrosion as well as disintegration, alkaline medium still provides non-noble metals increased stability, extending catalysis and making it a preferable option to acidic catalysis [93]. Alkaline water electrolysis, one of the most extensively used technologies in the field, is crucial in this respect since it may be used to treat discharged alkaline water, such as in water-alkali as well as chlor-alkali electrolysers [94,95]. Such technologies also demand a lot of energy, water-alkali, as well as chlor-alkali electrolysers, accounted for up to 25% to 30% of the electrical energy used in the United States (US) [92]. Other basic sciences often use the HER in an alkaline media to search for modern perspectives. A relatively few electrocatalysts that can be compared with Pt in an alkaline media in the form of reaction efficiency have already been reported up to this point [96]. As a result, the reaction mechanism must be investigated, and fundamental rules of electrode kinetics must be established, which can serve as a basis for researchers looking for novel and efficient electrocatalysts [94]. As opposed to the acidic circumstances, where the Volmer step irreversibly electrochemically dissociates water into adsorbed OH and H* species [91], instead of pursuing the covalently dative connection of the ion of hydronium, which might readily be followed either, the catalyst in an alkaline media has to break the larger covalent HOH bond before adsorbing H* [100]. Based on a comprehensive analysis of theoretical hypotheses and experimental results conducted by Yang et al., it has been determined that PEM systems require significant amounts of platinum (Pt) or Pt/C loadings for optimal operation, resulting in substantial cost escalation. This is primarily due to the relatively slow kinetics of the HER, which directly influences the overall cost considerations [101]. Consequently, acquiring in-depth insights into the catalytic processes involved in alkaline HER becomes crucially important, as it holds the potential to facilitate the development of robust catalysts that can enhance the economic viability of PEM systems [102].
