The interplay between surface chemistry and the electrical structure of electrocatalysts is crucial in understanding the various reaction phenomena mentioned above. Numerous efforts have been undertaken to develop innovative active catalysts in alkaline environments [94]. Overall, the electrocatalytic differences between HER and OER can be discussed as electrocatalysts used for HER are involved in the reduction of H2 to produce H. These electrocatalysts promote the reduction process. Typically, commonly used catalysts for the HER are composed of materials such as Pt and Pd. These materials are efficient in facilitating the conversion of protons into H2. Conversely, OER refers to the process of oxidising water (H2O) to generate oxygen gas (O2), as well as protons and electrons. Electrocatalysts for OER assist in facilitating the oxidation reaction. In addition, IrO2 as well as RuO2 are often used as electrocatalysts for the OER [104]. 3 MXene MXenes are a class of 2D materials that have attracted significant attention since their discovery in 2011. MXenes comprise transition metal carbides and nitrides, representing a new and exciting family of 2D materials [105–107]. MXenes are typically synthesized by selectively etching aluminium, silicon, gallium, or aluminium carbide layers from layered ceramic materials known as MAX phases. Unlike other 2D materials such as graphene, MXenes have high metallic conductivity and are hydrophilic due to the presence of hydroxyl and oxygen groups on their surfaces. These properties make MXenes promising candidates for various applications, including energy storage, catalysis, and sensing [108]. MXenes have exceptional metallic conductivity and high volumetric capacitance. These properties are due to the unique structure of MXenes, which are made up of thin layers of transition metal carbides or nitrides. The layers are held together by weak van der Waals forces, which makes them easy to exfoliate and disperse in solvents. Additionally, MXenes exhibit hydrophilic characteristics, enabling favourable interactions with water molecules. This property makes them easy to process and manipulate. These can be effectively processed into stable colloidal solutions using aqueous and organic solvents. MXene solutions can be further filtered to yield freestanding films. Furthermore, MXenes can be applied through spray-coating techniques, producing transparent conductive coatings [109]. Ti3C2 MXene was the first MXene to be synthesized, and it was initially studied for its electrochemical properties for batteries and supercapacitors [110]. The distinctive feature of MXenes lies in their extensive colour spectrum, encompassing the entire visible range. This remarkable characteristic renders MXenes highly favourable for a myriad of applications in optoelectronics, plasmonics, and photonics [111]. Notably, MXenes have demonstrated exceptional proficiency in converting light into heat, which holds significant potential for photodynamic cancer therapy [112]. Moreover, owing to their diverse composition and structure, certain MXenes exhibit superior electrochemical performance and stability, making them highly promising contenders for deployment as electrodes in supercapacitors, as well as for facilitating efficient electrochemical water-splitting systems [113]. The titanium carbide MXene (Ti3C2T x ) has also attracted significant attention in electrochemical water splitting, emerging as a highly researched MXene material [114–116]. The electro-catalytic characteristics of niobium carbide MXene (Nb2CT x ) have also been investigated in water splitting [117,118]. The compound has shown favourable performance in terms of both HER and OER. Moreover, molybdenum carbide MXene (Mo2CT x ) has also been the subject of research in electrochemical water splitting, showing its potential as an electrocatalyst [119]. Furthermore, research has explored the potential of vanadium carbide MXene (V2CT x ) in water-splitting processes, particularly focusing on its effectiveness in the OER [120]. Similarly, recent investigations have delved into the electro-catalytic characteristics of tantalum carbide MXene (Ta4C3T x ) in water splitting, emphasizing its performance in the OER [120]. Chromium carbide MXene (Cr2CT x ) has been a subject of study as a material for water-splitting applications, specifically for the HER [120]. On the other hand, the double transition metal (DTM) Mo2TiC2T x , a composite MXene material comprising molybdenum and titanium carbides, has been extensively examined for both HER and OER in water splitting [121]. Similarly, the catalytic properties of another DTM MXene, Mo2Ti2C3T x , consisting of molybdenum and titanium carbides, have been extensively investigated for their role in water-splitting reactions, attracting considerable attention [122]. 4 Advantages of MXenes over other 2D materials There have been reports of several 2D materials, including transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD), hexagonal boron nitrides (h-BN), graphene, etc., because of their essential characteristics like electrical conductivity [123], low density [123], large surface area [124], adhesion [125], optical [126], magnetic property [127], photoelectronic [128], biocompatible [129], luminescence [130], thermal expansion [131], hydrophilic [132], and so on. In contrast to the aforementioned materials, MXenes exhibit advantageous characteristics stemming from their adjustable electric and magnetic properties. For instance, although pure 2D graphene boasts remarkable electrical conductivity, it demonstrates inadequate magnetic properties, rendering it unsuitable for applications requiring electromagnetic impedance (EMI) shielding. Such applications necessitate materials with moderate conductivity and magnetic dipoles capable of interacting with electromagnetic (EM) waves. On the other hand, molybdenum disulphide (MoS2) is a 2D material consisting of dichalcogenides with a layered structure [133,134]. MoS2 is a semiconductor with a bandgap of approximately 1.2 eV and MXene have around 0.96 eV as per previous report [135]. The magnitude of the bandgap can be adjusted by exploiting the quantum confinement effect resulting from different surface morphologies. In its pure form, MoS2 exhibits lower conductivity and permittivity due to a less efficient charge transfer system compared to graphene. In contrast, MXenes exhibit remarkable conductivity spanning from metallic to semiconductor behaviour, and they offer advantages such as low-cost synthesis as well as improved hydrophilicity [136]. Overall, the advantages of MXenes over other 2D materials based on various factors are demonstrated in schematic illustration (Fig. 4 ). Both reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and graphene oxide (GO) exhibit characteristics of semiconductors and insulators when considered individually [137]. On the other hand, 2D TMDs demonstrate semiconducting behaviour. MXenes exhibit tunable electrical characteristics, allowing for the manifestation of metallic, semiconducting, superconducting, topologically protected, and, notably, half-metallic behavior [138–140]. Controlling terminal groups, providing doping, or using electric fields, as well as strain engineering may all be used to modify the half-metallicity found in MXenes. The unique half-metallic nature of MXenes holds promising prospects for advancements in the field of spintronics as well [141]. MXene-based materials exhibit superior structural and chemical stability, as well as exceptional heat resistance, surpassing GO membranes in these aspects. The integration of nanochannels within the layers of the MXene membrane has the potential to facilitate ultra-fast water flow, as reported in a study [142]. The MXene membrane, possessing a significantly shortened transport pathway and a large number of nanochannels, demonstrates notable water permeance and rejection rate, with values of 1000 L/m2 h and 90%, respectively. In contrast, GO substrates display a high resistance to organic solvents, whereas MXene barriers are susceptible to both aqueous systems [143]. The enhanced water flux observed in the MXene membrane can be attributed to its loosely lamellar structure, which provides an advantageous pathway for solution flow. Energy storage and conversion are becoming increasingly important as the world transitions to a more sustainable energy future. Various types of batteries, such as lithium-ion (Li-ion), potassium-ion (K-ion), sodium-ion (Na-ion) batteries, and supercapacitors, are well-established solutions for energy storage [144–147]. These electrochemical energy storage systems possess distinctive characteristics, including longer lifespan, desired current density, high power density, and environmental compatibility, which make them superior choices for emerging energy storage devices [148]. However, toward efficient energy conversion systems, using one-dimensional (1D) or 2D carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene-based materials as electrode materials has gained considerable attention [149]. This choice is motivated by their structural performance, excellent conductivity, and large surface areas. However, it is worth noting that metal oxides/hydroxides suffer from inferior electrical conductivity, leading to modest long-cycle activity and potential densities. Furthermore, 2D TMD nanosheets, such as MoSe2, tend to aggregate due to their high surface potential [150]. Consequently, the high resistance exhibited by MoSe2 when used as electrode materials poses a significant challenge. Given these constraints, MXenes have emerged as a viable option for electrode materials in electrochemical energy conversion systems [151]. Their distinctive structure, characterized by a metal-oxide-like surface and an inner metal carbide layer, facilitates the presence of active sites, promotes fast reaction kinetics, and efficiently supports electron transfer mechanisms [152]. These beneficial properties make MXenes a promising alternative for improving electrochemical activity, particularly in water-splitting applications [153]. The synthesis systems employed for MXenes present notable drawbacks, along with an inadequate understanding of their surface science. These aspects necessitate further investigation and offer promising prospects for future innovative applications. Chemical etching and delamination techniques result in terminal functional groups and defects on the outer layer of MXenes, and the variation in the number of layers can significantly impact their physical properties. Thus, it is crucial to explore methods for achieving controlled surface termination. Additionally, the presence of granular features hampers large-scale production of MXenes, resulting in substrate-dependent properties that restrict their widespread applicability in potential uses [154–156]. Significant advancements have been made in the field of MXene combinations and the understanding of MXene surface properties [157]. Notably, MXenes have demonstrated remarkable HER activity, which is considered one of their primary strengths. The presence of transition metal (M) active sites on their surface chemistry contributes to a significant enhancement in catalytic efficiency and a reduction in overpotentials. In comparison to several other 2D materials, MXenes have exhibited superior electrocatalytic performance for HER [158]. Additionally, MXenes exhibit exceptional chemical stability when exposed to aqueous conditions, which is crucial for maintaining their catalytic activity over extended periods. This distinguishes them from materials susceptible to corrosion or deterioration during water-splitting reactions [159]. MXenes also offer high versatility and compatibility with various substrates, making them suitable for integrating diverse electrode materials. This versatility significantly enhances their practicality in different electrochemical scenarios [160]. Lastly, environmental considerations play a significant role. Recent observations indicate that the manufacturing methods of MXene demonstrate a higher degree of environmental friendliness, aligning with the growing emphasis on sustainability and Green chemistry in materials science and technology, except for systems containing HF [161]. 5 MXene synthesis MXenes are synthesized through the selective removal of the A layer from the precursor MAX phase, denoted as M n +1AX n , wherein A represents elements from groups (13) and (14) (IIIA or IVA) of the periodic table. Although Al and Si are the most commonly used A elements, other elements such as Ga, In, Cd, Sn, As, S, and Pb can replace Al or Si [162]. The transition metal M and the X atom interaction involves a unique blend of metallic, ionic, and covalent bonding attributes. Conversely, the M–A bonds exclusively manifest metallic characteristics. As a result, the M–A bond (metallic) is comparatively weaker than the M–X bond (covalent). Employing a suitable etchant makes it possible to break the M–A bond, resulting in the removal of the A layer components [163]. As a result, targeted etching of A elements such as Al, Si, Ga, and Cd results in the formation of layered M n +1AX n with a characteristic “accordion-like” structure. At times, M n +1X n T x is used, where T denotes the surface functional group, such as O, F, OH, H2O, and Cl, or a combination of them [164]. Among the commercially available MAX phases, Ti3AlC2 is extensively utilized, making it a prominent focus in MXene research. Specifically, Ti3C2T x is the variant of choice, which is synthesized through a selective chemical etching process. The synthesis of MXenes typically employs two primary strategies: wet chemical etching and dry etching. Wet chemical etching entails the utilization of hydrofluoric acid (HF) as an etching agent, accompanied by dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as a delaminating agent, with the assistance of sonication. However, the preference lies with the dry etching technique due to its ability to achieve a surface termination free from fluorine compounds. The following section presents a comprehensive discussion on both approaches concerning the preparation of MXenes. 5.1 Wet chemical etching Wet chemical etching follows the top-down technique to produce MXene, where large-size crystals are exfoliated into mono-layer MXene. Typically, HF is widely used to etch the MAX phase, as initially demonstrated by Naguib et al. [165]. In their pioneering work, Ti3AlC2 was subjected to a 50% HF treatment under ambient conditions for 2 h. This process yielded Ti3C2T x , and the chemical reactions governing this transformation are shown in Eqs. (13) and (14). (13) M n +1AX n + 3HF = M n +1X n (s) + AF3 + 1.5H2 (g) (14) M n +1X n (s) + 2HF = M n +1X n F2 + H2 (g) The elimination of the A layer relies on the interaction between A and F ions, resulting in the formation of H2 as a by-product. Additionally, introducing functional groups (T x ), such as –F, –OH, and –Cl, induces a weakening of the M n +1X n bonding, ultimately leading to the formation of MXene. Furthermore, HF was employed as an etching agent to successfully synthesize various MXenes, including Ti2C, Mo2C, and Cr2TiC2 [166]. This process involves stirring the MAX phase precursor powder with HF under ambient conditions, which leads to etching the A layer and introducing functional groups onto the multilayer MXene surface. Subsequent centrifugation and washing until the pH reaches approximately 6 to obtain a few-layer MXene [167]. Furthermore, it has been observed that treating MXene with organic intercalants like DMSO leads to the delamination of MXene into a single layer, while conventional ultrasonication causes exfoliation of the few layers, as depicted in Fig. 5 (a), exhibiting an accordion-like structure [168]. In order to achieve in-situ HF etching and avoid using harsh etchants like HF, a combination of fluoride salt and acid (LiF + HCl) was applied to treat the MAX phase. This novel etching approach successfully eliminated the need for direct HF usage, which can cause molarity variations (HCl, 6 to 12 M) that may affect both the accordion-like morphology and properties of MXene. By utilizing the LiF/HCl mixture as the etchant, Li+ ions could intercalate between the layers of MXene, leading to the degradation of interlayer bonding and the generation of delaminated MXene sheets after the etching and washing steps. Notably, both HF and in-situ HF etching (LiF + HCl) initiated from the edges of Al sites (A layer) in the MAX phase and proceeded inward, sequentially exposing the inner atoms to the etchant in a layer-by-layer etching manner [172]. Other salts are also reported to etch Ti3AlC2, like HCl/FeF3, adopting the same mechanism of Fe n + intercalation into MXene layers as shown in Fig. 5(b), whereas Fe3+ can lead to oxidation of MXene, decreasing its yield [173,174]. Molten salt etching, a minimally intensive layer delamination (MILD) etching commonly referred to as fluorine-free etching, presents a viable strategy for treating the MAX phase. This method involves using molten salts, such as CuCl2, ZnCl2, FeCl2, and AgCl. Unlike HF and in-situ HF etching of MXene, which results in MXene surfaces terminated with –F, thereby reducing conductivity, molten salt treatment introduces –Cl surface terminations. The selective etching of the MAX phase is achieved through the cation-induced oxidation of the A layer [175]. The synthesis process is based on redox coupling of A layer and cations. Initially, Ti3AlC2 MAX was immersed in molten salt, specifically CuCl2, at a temperature of 700 °C. Alternatively, the salt used could be CuBr2 or CuI2. The presence of Cu2+ cations facilitates the oxidation of Al atoms within the MAX phase, resulting in the formation of Al3+. Additionally, Cu2+ cations interact with Ti3C2, leading to the formation of Cu. In this context, Cu+ and Cl− can be considered analogous to H+ and –F in the HF etching system. To obtain Ti3C2Cl2 and remove the Cu atoms, the resulting product was subjected to treatment with an ammonium persulfate (APS) solution, as illustrated in Fig. 5(c) [176]. The reaction mechanism for molten salt etching is as follows. (15) Ti3AlC2 + 2CuCl2 → Ti3C2 + AlC4 (g) + 2Cu (16) Ti3C2 + CuCl2 → Ti3C2Cl2 + Cu Moreover, electrochemical etching follows the selective etching of A layer when operated in a specified potential range where MAX is used as an electrode in the electrochemical cell, demonstrated in Fig. 5(c). The selection of an appropriate electrolyte plays a critical role in determining the desired surface termination of the material. Various electrolytes such as HF, HCl, or NaCl can be employed. During cyclic voltammetry, the M–A bonds typically break within a potential range of 0–2.5 V, leading to the etching of the A layer. However, precise potential modulation is crucial to achieving optimal etching results. In a recent investigation, the efficacy of Ti3AlC2 was assessed as both the working and counter electrodes in different electrolytes, including H2SO4, HNO3, NaOH, NH4Cl, and FeCl3. Nonchlorine-based electrolytes were observed to be incapable of etching the A layer, whereas chlorine-based electrolytes effectively removed the A layer from the MAX precursor [177]. To further customize the surface of MXene, a one-pot method involving molten salt-assisted electrochemical etching was proposed. In this approach, a 2 V potential was applied at 450 °C using a Ti3AlC2 anode and a nickel cathode in an electrochemical setup. Consequently, the A layer underwent oxidation and subsequent removal [178]. Alkali etching is another method that utilizes NaOH and H2SO4 subsequently to etch the MAX, as shown in Fig. 5(c) [179]. Recently, Ding et al. proposed an innovative approach to modifying the structures of MXenes and MAX phases, referred to as the “chemical scissor” technique [180]. The authors delineated four distinct reaction pathways integral to this structural modification process. Firstly, the Lewis acid molten salt (LAMS) scissors leverage the variance in redox potential between Lewis acidic cations and A elements to generate non-van der Waals (vdW) gaps in MAX phases. Secondly, metal atoms permeate into vacancies, fostering the formation of MAX phases and reducing the chemical energy of the system. Thirdly, metal scissors and electron injection are employed to eliminate surface terminations in multilayer MXenes, resulting in the creation of vdW gaps. Lastly, anions coordinate with oxidized early transition metal atoms, giving rise to terminated MXenes, as illustrated in Fig. 6 (a). The periodic table in Fig. 6(b) highlights the elements present in MAX phases and MXenes. In addition to conventional main-group elements such as Al, Ga, and Sn, uncommon elements, such as Bi, Sb, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Pt, Au, Pd, Ag, Cd, and Rh are intercalated into MAX phases. The –P and –Sb terminations (group (15) elements) are also illustrated, in addition to the available halogen (–Cl, –Br, and –I) and chalcogen (–S, –Se, and –Te) terminations. The Ti3C2 layers are reconstructed to generate the MAX phases (Ti3GaC2, Ti3AlC2, and Ti3SnC2), as confirmed by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns in Fig. 6(c). Atomically resolved scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images in Fig. 6(d–h) validate the phase transformation from Ti3C2Cl2 MXene to non-terminated Ti3C2 and then to the final reconstructed MAX phases. Furthermore, removal of Cl terminations from Ti3C2Cl2 results in wide gaps in non-terminated Ti3C2, as shown in Fig. 6(e). Additionally, when using Al and intercalant metal Cd as the metal scissors, Ti3Cd2C2 with a double layer of Cd is synthesized, as illustrated in Fig. 6(i). Through methods III and II, the multilayer Ti3C2Cl2 MXene is reassembled into multilayer Ti3AlC2 using chemical scissor Al. The distinct (0002) diffraction peaks of Ti3C2Cl2 and Ti3AlC2, which significantly broaden after three cycles of interconversion due to reduced layer thickness, provide evidence of successful interconversion, as demonstrated in Fig. 6(j). Finally, completely exfoliated Ti3AlC2 and Ti3C2Cl2 lamellae are observed (Fig. 6k–n). In the final reconstruction process, Sn is employed as an intercalant, forming Ti3SnC2 nanosheets from Ti3C2Cl2 nanosheets, as shown in Fig. 6(o). STEM images confirm that Ti3SnC2 nanosheets belong to a family of metal-intercalated 2D carbides in which Sn atom monolayers intercalate neighbouring Ti3C2 lamellae but have –C terminations on the outermost surface, as depicted in Fig. 6(p) [180]. 5.2 Dry etching The dry etching of MXene follows the bottom-up synthesis approach. Numerous approaches, such as chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and plasma-modified MXene [181], have been developed as viable alternatives to produce MXenes without using fluoric acid. Therefore, considering their inherent complexity, developing effective and feasible modern protocols is crucial for synthesizing MXenes through bottom-up methods. By utilizing these methods, it becomes possible to gain insights into MXene properties, as demonstrated in the synthesis of Mo2C [182] and MoN through the bottom-up technique, which revealed the presence of defects and facilitated the exploration of their intrinsic properties [183]. Generally, the CVD technique is frequently employed as a promising alternative to fluoride-free pathways for fabricating 2D nanosheets [184]. The CVD method was employed to synthesize Mo2C MXene in a related investigation. The experimental setup involved placing a copper (Cu) foil substrate on a molybdenum (Mo) foil. Methane gas was utilized as the carbon source, and the temperature was set at 1085 °C, surpassing the melting point of Cu. As a result, Cu dissolved and formed a Cu-Mo alloy at the interface. Subsequently, Mo atoms diffused across the interface and reacted with the carbon provided by methane, leading to the disintegration of the alloy and the growth of ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals with a minimum thickness of 3 nm [185]. This process is similar to graphene CVD fabrication, illustrated in Fig. 5(c). In recent developments, theoretical studies have explored the production of fluorine-free MXene through the dry selective extraction (DSE) of MXene. Computational screening using the density functional theory (DFT) module has been employed to identify stable MXene structures, such as the well-known Ti3C2. The removal of aluminium from the MAX phase has been achieved using gaseous etchants, including I2, resulting in halogen-terminated MXene. The reaction mechanism follows a solid–vapor reaction between the MAX phase and the halogen etchant. Notably, the low melting and boiling points of the reactants and halide by-products contribute to producing high-quality MXene. Furthermore, using a carrier gas to remove by-products during the reaction enables one-step etching and eliminates the need for additional washing protocols. It is crucial to carefully consider the appropriate etching parameters, such as source gas pressure and reaction temperature, as they directly impact the quality of the resulting MXene. Thus, the DSE approach offers a more reliable and environmentally safe method for MXene synthesis compared to other techniques [186]. A recent study has introduced a fluorine- and acid-free approach for etching MXene. This method utilizes a physical vacuum distillation technique, which can be applied to various MXenes, including Ti3C2T x , Ti2NT x , Ti3CNT x , and Nb4CT x . In this one-step process, the low-boiling-point A element in the MAX phase is evaporated in a tube furnace under an inert atmosphere. As a result, the physical vacuum distillation method enables the production of controllable and scalable MXene with chlorine surface termination [187]. Furthermore, an enhanced pulsed laser deposition technique has been employed to synthesize fluorine-free MXene. In this approach, a Mo2C film was synthesized by reacting Mo vapours generated through a pulsed laser with CH4 plasma. The resulting Mo2C film was then deposited on a sapphire substrate [188]. These bottom-up approaches in synthesizing fluorine-free MXene exhibit promising outcomes, highlighting their potential for producing high-quality MXenes. A comprehensive overview of various MXenes synthesis methods, including their associated parameters, is presented in Table 1 . 6 Structures of MXenes MXene is typically derived from the parent MAX phases and represented by the M n +1X n framework. The schematics of four common MXene structures and their composition based on the periodic table can be observed in Fig. 7 (a) [208]. In MAX, the variable n can have values of 1, 2, and 3. The resulting MXenes possess the M1.33X, M2X, M3X2, and M4X3 lattice structures with 3, 5, and 7 atomic layers, respectively. While MXenes inherit a hexagonal close-packed crystal (HCP) structure, recent research has reported an ABABAB HCP arrangement for M2X and ABCABC FCC patterns for M3X2 and M4X3 [167]. Fig. 7(b) shows atomistic models of various structures of MXenes known to date [209]. The atomic lattice of HCP MXene is P63/mmc, where M atoms have HCP arrangement and X atoms are attached to octahedral interstitial sites. The terminal functional groups could be adjusted either on top of the M layer, in gaps between the top M layer or in the gap between consecutive X layer stacking. Changing M in the structural lattice of MXene produces the ordered MXenes and solid solutions. One form of M metal is present at the basal plane of an ordered MXene, known as an in-plane (i-MXene) structure, with ordered vacancies at other locations. The second sort of MXene structure is an out-of-plan structure, which is made up of two distinct metals M forming double layers and sandwiched between them. Furthermore, the MXene structure is recognized as a solid solution if the double metal component is arbitrarily ordered [210]. 7 Crystallinity and morphology of MXenes The successive steps of obtaining multilayer MXene from MAX phase and delaminating it could be observed from shifts in XRD patterns. For instance, in widely explored Ti3AlC2 MAX (Fig. 8 a), the crystallographic peaks are associated with p63/mmc space symmetry. After treating MAX with an etchant, the prominent peaks within 30° to 40° are eliminated in MXene production. The XRD shows the purity of MXene phase as the higher order peaks reduce and the peak at (002) plan shifts to a lower angle range of approximately 8.6° when completely delaminated. The shift in the MAX peak (002) depicts the removal of Al-layer, while also peak reduction at 39° shows substantial removal of aluminum atoms [211]. Additionally, the shift observed at the starting angle (8.6°) could potentially be attributed to the intercalation of ions from the delaminating agent, such as organic solvents. A clear illustration can be seen in Fig. 8(b) for Ti3SiC2 MAX etching and delamination. Again, the shift in the peak corresponding to the (002) plane indicates the etching of the Si layer from the precursor. However, the (104) plane corresponding to the Si peak disappears after etching and MXene delamination. Furthermore, the intercalation of tetrabutylammonium utilized to delaminate the exfoliated MXene is shown by a further shift in the (002) peak towards lower angle values following delamination [214]. Similarly, a prominent shift in XRD patterns gives information on the partial or complete etching/delamination and intercalation of ions to expand the interlayer spacing. For example, Ti3AlC2 was etched by NH4HF2 under various time constraints at 60 °C. After 2 h, the etching process reached at its completion, leading to a noticeable decrease in the intensity of the Al peak located at 39.2° , which gradually diminished further with prolonged time intervals. Furthermore, the peak at 8.6° exhibited a reduction in intensity due to the intercalation of NH4 + ions, as visually represented in Fig. 8(c). The elevated temperature treatment for etching out MAX also affects the final MXene quality. Fig. 8(d) shows that rising temperature produces more MXene (60 °C). However, the oxidation of MXene may occur at higher temperatures. The flake size or diameter of the MAX phase has a notable impact on the etching mechanism, as depicted in Fig. 8(e). With a decrease in the powder diameter of Ti3AlC2, the etching process becomes easier, resulting in the transformation of Ti3C2 peaks with higher intensities. Besides, the intercalation effect of NH4 + in expanding the interlayer distance can be observed in Fig. 8(f) [213]. The XRD analysis provides crucial insights into the etching process from MAX to MXene. However, further investigation is required to obtain additional data on delamination, interlayer spacing, and intercalations. Initially, HF acid was commonly used for MXene etching, forming the distinctive “accordion” morphology. This lamellar structure has since become a hallmark of successful MXene etching. However, it is important to note that MXene treated with different etchants may not always exhibit conventional structures. In the case of V4AlC3 (Fig. 9 a) etches to V4C3T x , the layered structure of MAX after etching transforms to an accordion-like structure of MXene supported by EDX, showing the removal of Al layer as the Al peaks intensity reduces in (Fig. 9b) producing multilayer MXene [215]. A similar effect can be seen in Fig. 9(c and d) for high entropy MAX phase and MXene (Fig. 9e and f) multilayer, (Fig. 9g and h) single flake and film, respectively. Al layer of the multilayer product was selectively etched using a 48% HF etchant that was highly concentrated, resulting in an accordion-like structure. The delamination process involved the utilization of tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) to produce individual flakes [216]. However, reducing the HF concentration does not consistently result in the formation of an accordion-like structure. Nevertheless, a comparable outcome is observed through SEM analysis of MAX phase materials, and, in the case of MILD etching techniques, both hold significance in various application domains. 8 Electrochemical applications of MXenes Electrochemical investigations of MXenes have mostly focused on their application as electrodes in batteries and supercapacitors, which are cases of electrochemical energy storage technologies [217,218]. MXenes have been discovered to have high capacitance and quick charge/discharge rates, making them attractive candidates to use in high-performance energy storage devices [219,220]. MXenes have also been investigated as electrocatalysts for a variety of electrochemical processes, along with the HER [221,222], OER [223–225], oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [226–228], electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) [229–231], nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [232,233], and energy storage materials [234–236], respectively (Fig. 10 a). Moreover, MXenes have been shown to have high electrocatalytic activity, making them intriguing materials for application in energy conversion systems. Electrochemical sensors are another interesting usage of MXenes in electrochemistry [237–239]. Because of their excellent electrical conductivity and distinctive surface chemistry, MXenes are employed as sensing materials, especially for detecting heavy metal ions and organic pollutants in water [240,241]. 8.1 MXene based electrocatalysts for HER The electrocatalytic mechanism of MXenes for the HER involves multiple phases [243,244]. The overall process can be described as the adsorption of hydrogen ions (protons) at the interface of the MXene catalyst, followed by proton reduction to generate hydrogen gas molecules and subsequent desorption of the hydrogen gas molecules from the surface of catalyst [245]. The specific details and processes associated with each stage may vary depending on the MXene material and reaction conditions [246]. Notably, the high surface area, strong electrical conductivity, and favorable electrochemical properties of MXenes facilitate the adsorption, reduction, and desorption of hydrogen ions and gas [247]. Consequently, efforts were undertaken to improve the performance of MXenes with O*/OH*-terminated surfaces [242], which resulted in enough increase in exchange current and a boost in hydrogen evolution (as shown in Fig. 10b and c). The GH has been computed to estimate that the adsorption sites again for HER, were the surface oxygen atoms. These oxygen atoms aided in the synergy of H* with 2D MXenes. Following investigation, it was discovered that the HER procedure on O-terminated MXenes resembled the Heyrovsky mechanism. The HER activity of MXenes with various surface groups (–O, –OH, and –F) was investigated (Fig. 11 a–d). Notably, the O-terminated surface performed better than the –OH and –F terminated surfaces. The research has shown that altering the surface termination may be used to manipulate the catalytic effectiveness of HER catalysts derived from 2D MXenes [248]. Fig. 11(e–g) demonstrated the outstanding electrocatalytic activity of Ti3C2O x nanosheets in the HER process, having a much lower overpotential of 190 mV at a current density of 10 mA/cm2 than Ti3C2(OH) x (217 mV) and Ti3C2T x -450 (266 mV). The extremely active –O sites found on the basal plane of Ti3C2O x MXenes were ascribed to the increased performance, as demonstrated by Tafel plot value of 60.7 mV/dec. These findings provide the groundwork for enhancing the effectiveness of MXenes-based HER electrocatalysts by altering their surface termination groups [6]. In contrast, advancements in the electrochemical methodologies of MXenes for the HER have been documented. According to the findings of Zhi et al., Ti2CT x exhibits moderate HER activity; however, it functions as a suboptimal catalyst, requiring a 609 mV overpotential to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2 during the initial sweep [252]. In addition, Handoko et al. used LSV at a scan rate of 10 mV/s to describe the electrochemical HER performance of Ti3C2T x through an overpotential range of 538 mV at 10 mA/cm2 current density. In 0.5 M H2SO4, the catalyst was evaluated in a three-electrode electrochemical cell with a rotating disk electrode (RDE) at 1600 r/min [243]. Huang et al. presented the hydrothermal approach for the in situ development of MoS2 nanosheets vertically standing at top planar Ti3C2 nanosheets to construct hierarchical heterostructures. Their material showed an overpotential value of 280 mV in 0.5 M H2SO4 [49]. Moreover, Wang et al. constructed the TiOF2@Ti3C2T x through a simple synthesis strategy with TiOF2 intercalation to promote the durability as well as activity of Ti3C2T x , having an overpotential of 197 mV at a current density value of 10 mA/cm2 [253]. Lie et al. created a hierarchical “nanoroll”-like MoS2/Ti3C2T x hybrid using liquid nitrogen freezing and subsequently annealing. The overpotential of the produced MoS2/Ti3C2T x electrocatalyst was 152 mV [254]. Additionally, Ma et al. have successfully achieved the in-situ development of hydrazone-linked covalent organic framework (COF-42) nanocrystals with a distinct nanoflower-shaped structure on 2D ultrathin Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets (COF/Ti3C2T x ) using a facile and strong stereo assembly technique [255]. Remarkably, the combination of COF-42 and Ti3C2T x nanosheets provides a network of porous channels at different scales, facilitating the rapid movement of electrolytes and electrons. Additionally, this combination allows for the complete exposure and activation of several catalytically active sites. Consequently, the optimized COF/Ti3C2T x nanoarchitecture exhibits outstanding HER features, including a very low onset potential of 19 mV, a modest Tafel slope of 50 mV /dec, and consistent long-term durability. These parameters are equivalent to those of the commercially available Pt/C catalyst. Tie et al. developed a theoretical and experimental technique for an activated electrocatalyst of HER relying on Ti3C2T x /Ni3S2/NF. At 10 mA/cm2, the Ti3C2T x /Ni3S2/NF material displayed an overpotential of 72 mV (in 1 M KOH medium) [256]. The runny and photoinduced reduction approach was used to load Pt onto various altered Ti3C2T x -based (T = O, OH, and F) MXene supports. The designed catalyst achieves a 55 mV overpotential at a 10 mA/cm2 current density. The surface terminals (Ti-OH or Ti-O) of the altered Ti3C2T x have an impact on Pt's electronic state, which in turn affects the overpotential. The improved charge transfer between the O terminals and Pt accelerated the HER kinetics and, therefore, the total catalytic performance [257]. Interestingly, Huang et al. showcased the rational design and manageable production of perforated Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets closely integrated with ultrathin Ni-Fe LDHs (LDH/H-Ti3C2T x ) using a combined approach of in situ oxidative etching and hydrothermal assembly [258]. This newly developed nanoarchitecture features a significant number of in-plane holes, which serve to create a complex 3D ion diffusion model. This model effectively reduces the distance that reactants need to travel, resulting in faster electrochemical HER as well as OER kinetics. Additionally, the nanoarchitecture exposes a large number of catalytically active sites and ensures a high rate of charge transfer, further enhancing the acceleration of the electrochemical reactions. Another study by Ma et al. reported iron-based metal–organic frameworks (MIL-100) as well as Ti3C2T x MXene nanosheets (MIL/Ti3C2T x ) through an in situ solvothermal assembly technique [259]. The incorporation of MIL-100 nanocrystals between the layers of Ti3C2T x nanoflakes prevents them from restacking and clumping together. As a result, there is a significant enhancement in the combined effects of these materials, demonstrating improved electrocatalytic HER properties. These properties include a low onset potential of 29 mV, an operating overpotential of 107 mV at 10 mA/cm2, and a small Tafel slope of 61 mV/dec. Additionally, to Ti-based MXenes, C. Ling et al. advocated 2D MXenes that were completely oxidized vanadium carbides (V2CO2) for HER. They projected that these materials would have extraordinarily high catalytic activity [260]. Kuang et al. reported NiS2/V2CT x represented theoretical and experimental studies of the intrinsic and electrochemical performance toward HER with an overpotential value of 179 mV in 1 M KOH [261]. Yoon et al. prepared vanadium carbide MXene (V2CT x ) based on interfacial chemical doping with the non-metallic donor. This theoretical study predicted the activity of composite material with an overpotential of 163 mV at 10 mA/cm2 [262]. Furthermore, the surface functionalization of V2CT x MXene was explored as a successful approach to create a bifunctional hybrid electrocatalyst for water-splitting applications. This method involves carefully loading spherical silver nanoparticles (Ag-NPs) onto V2CT x nanosheets (NSs), showing an overpotential value of 32 mV, which is even more than Pt-based electrocatalysts [263]. However, the expansion of V2C MXene has been hindered due to the challenges associated with its demanding synthesis requirements and inherent physical instability. V2C MXene continues encountering numerous obstacles regarding synthesis techniques, structural characteristics, electrochemical energy storage capabilities, and its efficacy in energy conversion systems aimed at the HER [264]. Another class of MXene based on Mo also has an important role in HER. Denis et al. described the structural characteristics of Mo2CT x . Co was synthesized from a cobalt modified bulk moly carbide in two steps: intercalation Ga producing followed by HF elimination of Ga. This theoretical analysis anticipated a 180 mV overpotential in 0.5 M H2SO4 [265]. Carbon-coated few-layered MoS2 nanoplates were assembled on carbon-stabilized Ti3C2 MXene, hierarchies MoS2/Ti3C2-MXene@C integrates with superb structural stability, electrical properties, but instead stronger interfacial interconnections are fabricated, exhibiting incredible performance HER with an overpotential value of 135 mV (0.5 M H2SO4) [266]. Liang et al. developed a straightforward technique for increasing HER activity in an alkaline medium by combining Co-doped MoS2 with Mo2CT x MXene (Co-MoS2/Mo2CT x ), having an overpotential of 112 mV at 10 mA/cm2 in a basic environment [119]. In addition, with a small amount of precious metal (Pt), the electrochemical disintegration of double transition metal MXene nanosheets (Mo2TiC2T x ) along with numerous vulnerable basal planes and Mo vacancies in the outer layers was enabled by interactions between protons as well as the surface functional groups of Mo2TiC2T x was achieved; having an overpotential value of 30 mV, with a mass activation about 40 times that of the conventional platinum-on-carbon catalyst (in acidic medium) by Zhang et al. [267]. 8.2 HER analysis of MXene Fig. 12 (a) shows the LSV curves of various MAX phases and glassy carbon (GC) at a scan rate of 5 mV/sec through the recently reported work by Shaik et al. [69]. Its distinct structure arrangement is identified as the contributing factor behind the boosted HER performance exhibited by Mo2TiAlC2 compared to other MXene variants. Mo2TiAlC2 displayed an overpotential of −0.57 V compared to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), surpassing all other MXene types. This unequivocally demonstrates that MXenes comprising Mo, Ti, and V elements rank among the top catalysts for HER activity and O-terminated Nb2C with one O vacancy from the same research work. It is evident that Pd/Nb2C-HF, Pd/Nb2C-H2SO4, and Pd/Nb2C-HNO3 all exhibit remarkable HER capabilities, indicated by overpotentials at 10 mA/cm2 of 34, 43, and 46 mV, respectively, relative to the RHE. Interestingly, the HER performance diminishes as the number of O functional groups increases or the number of F functional groups decreases. On the other hand, Nb2C particles display insignificant HER activity when not loaded with additional components [69]. Moreover, Kannan. et al. reported their research work for the HER via Mo2CT x and P-Mo2CT x [268], corresponding polarization curves along with Pt/C (20 wt%) are depicted in Fig. 12(b). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) makes it possible to determine the electrochemical impedance of the system with respect to the HER, which provides a quantifiable measure of the resistance to electron transport between the electrode and the electrolyte [269]. The EIS-based data (Nyquist plots) for various MXenes, as from recent reports [270,271], can be seen in Fig. 12(c and d). Associated Nyquist plots demonstrate a reduced semi-circle radius with superior performance to a quick charge mechanism (low charge transfer resistance), encouraging crucial MXene characteristics with desirable electrical conductivity. The impedance may be divided into R ct (charge transfer resistance), and solution resistance is measured. The charge transfer resistance reduces as the reaction progresses, representing the increased electron transport rate. On the other hand, its solution resistance is inversely proportional to the electrolyte solution's conductivity and unaffected by the electrode response [272]. Analysing impedance data at different frequencies can provide valuable insights into the response mechanism and kinetics. The slope of the impedance curve at shorter wavelengths provides information about the diffusion-limited nature of the reaction [273,274]. During the hydrogen evolution process, protons are converted into hydrogen gas at the surface of the electrocatalyst. However, the surface of the electrocatalyst may deteriorate gradually due to various factors, such as exposure to reactive species, electrochemical degradation, or mechanical wear. Consequently, the activity of the electrocatalyst may decline, leading to reduced efficiency and performance. Chronopotentiometry may assist in identifying alterations in the electrocatalyst throughout time and determining the material's stability [275]. This information may be utilized to increase the efficiency and endurance of HER electrocatalysts by optimizing their design. Fig. 12(e and f) illustrates the stability, as indicated by the desired chronopotentiometry results, with variations observed among different MXenes [271,276,277]. The research shows that R-CoC2O4@MXene can remain stable with minimal deterioration when subjected to current densities of 10, 500, and 1000 mA/m2 for 100 h [276]. On the other hand, MXenes-based composite (with ZIF-8) has shown promising stability in alkaline media for 20 h toward HER response, except for any major change within the potential range [271], as shown in Fig. 12(g). The LSV approach, conversely, may be used to do the durability test. In practice, the electrocatalyst is evaluated for durability before and after chronopotentiometry to ensure the electrocatalyst's durability. The reproduced data from recent research [271] demonstrated the durable behaviour of MXenes-based electrocatalysts through LSV analysis (before and after the chronopotentiometry test), as shown in Fig. 12(h). Electrochemical and structural stability The electrochemical stability of MXene, subjected to tests such as chronopotentiometry and chronoamperometry, can be evaluated through diverse physical characterizations. Among these, XRD is particularly crucial for assessing crystallinity. This analytical approach functions as a postmortem examination of the electrocatalyst, offering valuable insights into its structural stability (Fig. 13 a) [276]. In addition, A. Hanan et al. [278] reported post analysis of CoS2@Ti3C2T x composite for HER with stability of 60 h. The corresponding structural stability of MXene has been shown through its XRD pattern (Fig. 13b). Additionally, Yang et al. performed surface feature analysis on ultrathin (UT) Ti3C2T x after stability (chronopotentiometry) testing, evaluating its HER performance in an acidic medium (0.5 H2SO4) [279]. The SEM images of UT Ti3C2T x are given before and after chronopotentiometry analysis (Fig. 13c and d). The surface stability of MXene after HER performance can be evaluated using SEM images, which serve as evidence of its durability over extended electrochemical testing periods. Furthermore, it is important to note that the longer electrochemical performance of various MXene-based electrocatalysts is heavily influenced by the composition of MXene itself, as well as the electrolyte used [280,281]. In general, a range of MXenes, such as those incorporating Ti, Mo, V, Nb, etc., have been systematically assessed for their applicability in electrochemical water-splitting systems. The electrochemical properties of these MXenes were carefully examined, and a summary of their comparative outcomes is provided in Table S1 (supplementary information). 9 Possible strategies to enhance HER activity Various strategies have been introduced that can lead to robust responses for HER regarding electrocatalysts’ composition, morphology, surface termination, impurity introduction, composite, etc. Fig. 14 provides a schematic illustration of these strategies, further described in Table S2. These approaches can be categorized based on their respective implications: 9.1 Thinning layers The MXene shows the stacking of several nanosheets, forming a multi-layered structure separated by nanosized gaps between layers known as interlayer spacing. The thickness of the layers varies based on the n number from the general formula M n +1X n T x . Thicker MXene layers typically require harsher etching conditions, such as higher HF concentrations or longer etching durations. This is often attributed to the stiffness, mechanical stress, and strength of the M–A bonds within the MXene structure. For instance, Mo2TiC2T x (n = 2) and Mo2TiC3T x (n = 3) require an etching time of 48 and 96 h in 50% HF, respectively [282]. Thinner MXene layers are beneficial for HER, where there is easier access to the active sites. Delamination to form the fewer-layer or single layer of ultrathin nanosheets offers more exposed termination groups and active sites than the bulk multi-layered MXene. MXene nanosheets may be obtained from sonication of multilayer MXenes, intercalation with strong polar solvents, or etching with LiF + HCl mixture [283]. The former is carried out for HF-etched MAX phases, while the latter typically results in a mix of multi-layers and few/single-layers [282]. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD), a bottom-up approach, can potentially produce ultrathin few-layered MXene. For example, the ultrathin Mo2C comprised a very thin few layers grown through CVD. The Mo2C shows good thermal and chemical stability, as well as a large surface area. Interestingly, Sun et al. found the overpotential of 340 mV at 10 mA/cm2 for a CVD-synthesised Mo2C in 0.5 M H2SO4, lower than the typical Ti3C2T x (>500 mV), despite the absence of termination groups [284]. The thickness of the Mo2C layers was around 6–14 nm. Additionally, the ball-milling approach is able to minimize the size of MXenes. Zhang et al. used ball-milling in the presence of red phosphorus to reduce the size of micro-sized multi-layered Ti3C2T x to nanodots having 2–5 nm thickness [285]. Ti–O–P bonds were also observed, which is a potential active site for the adsorption of intermediates for HER. However, it is difficult to remove red phosphorus after the synthesis process. Fan et al. partially exfoliated the Nb2CT x from its multi-layered structure through ball-milling in the presence of Pt precursors [286]. This allows the deposition of Pt nanoclusters on the surface of Nb2CT x simultaneously. The annealing treatment that follows resulted in the formation of Pt3Nb alloys. The thinned layers of Nb2CT x with Pt3Nb contributed to excellent HER activity in acidic electrolytes. While few-layer MXenes have several layers forming sheets of several nanometre thickness, single-layer MXenes comprise very thin individual nanosheets with thickness ranging from 1–2 nm [287]. The layers may appear folded due to the interactions between –F and –OH termination groups [288]. Numan et al. also determined that the BET surface area of a Ti3C2T x nanosheet is approximately 60.5 m2/g in addition to having mesopores [289]. Li et al obtained Ti3C2T x nanosheets with a thickness of around 1.35 nm through chemical etching and delamination with N-methyl-pyrrolidone (NMP) [46]. The nanosheets exhibit smaller onset HER overpotential compared to the Ti3CT x with layered structure. Furthermore, MXene nanosheets can also effectively coat conductive substrates such as nickel foam, which is then used to grow HER-active nanoparticles uniformly [290]. Recently, Wu et al. showed that ultrathin Mo2C MXene single layer with around 0.36 nm exhibited greater HER performance than the thicker multi-layered Mo2C [291]. It is also possible to further modify the morphology of MXene nanosheets to include holes or assembly into 3D porous structures. These morphologies have been shown to benefit the catalytic HER by providing a larger surface area for depositing HER-active nanoparticles and ease electrolyte access to active sites [292,293]. 9.2 Creation of active sites Surface functional groups (or the termination groups) on the MXenes basal planes are tailorable based on the etching conditions or further doping with other functional groups. Typically, HF or LiF + HCl etched MXenes consist of a combination of –F, –O, and –OH termination –F groups that may be dominant where its concentration increases with more concentrated HF used [165]. These termination groups are crucial as they are able to function as active sites for H-adsorption and desorption. Additionally, they must bind with HER-active phases to introduce more active sites to the MXenes. –O and –OH terminations were considered an excellent active site for H-adsorption on MXene. However, their effectiveness varies with the type of MXene. The hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔG H) of Ti2CO2 is near optimal and has good potential for HER. Ti3C2O2 and V2CO2 only displayed optimal ΔG H at large H coverage, while Nb2CO2 and Nb4C3O2 had weaker interactions with H, hence a more positive ΔG H than Ti2CO2 and Ti3C2O2 [242]. For the case of Nb2C, Zhang et al. determined the HF-etched Nb2C MXene, followed by treatment with H2SO4 or HNO3, resulted in varying concentrations of –O terminations, which changed the binding strength of the Nb2C with Pd clusters [294]. HF-etched Nb2C without further treatments that contain fluorine vacancies has the lowest overpotential at 34 mV at 10 m A/cm2 in 0.5 M H2SO4. This is due to the easier formation of Pd anions in the presence of F vacancies, stronger proton adsorption by –F and weaker H-adsorption ease the release of H2. While –F groups may be disadvantageous for HER in Ti3C2T x due to the more negative ΔG H (very strong H-adsorption) and high overpotentials as shown in some studies [243,295], the –F groups may benefit in adsorbing the HER-active phases, including the single atoms and nanoparticles. The effect of the –F groups towards HER kinetics also differs between MXenes like Nb2C and Ti3C2T x . 9.3 Enhancement of electron transport for HER The efficient electron transfer ability of electrocatalysts is desired to enhance the kinetics for hydrogen adsorption and desorption. The electron conductivity of Ti3C2T x may reach as high as 10,000 S/cm. Therefore, they are attractive for application in electrocatalytic HER [296,297]. Electronic properties of the MXene can be tailored/controlled through varying the type of transition metals, presence of termination groups, intercalants and whether the MXene is multi-layered or delaminated. Higher in-plane conductivity has been observed for the delaminated MXenes [298]. Termination groups may lead to the MXene being metallic or semi-conducting. Removing the termination groups improves the metallicity and electron conduction of the MXenes, such as those in Ti3C2T x , Mo2TiC2T x , and Ti3CNT x [299]. Compared to Ti3C2T x , Mo2CT x has been demonstrated to possess a semiconducting nature, while Ti3C2T x exhibits a predominantly metallic behaviour with commendable electron conductivity [300]. It is crucial to preserve the termination groups as they serve as active sites and enable binding to HER-active phases. Additionally, incorporating heteroatom doping can effectively modify the electron conductivity of MXenes, rendering them more advantageous for HER [301]. Owing to its conductivity, MXene helps to facilitate the electron transfer of HER-active phases. This is particularly advantageous for materials like MoS2, which possess relatively low intrinsic conductivity. The synergistic combination of –O and –OH functionalized Ti3C2T x with MoS2 results in a remarkable reduction in the charge transfer resistance associated with MoS2, consequently promoting faster kinetics for the HER [302]. Furthermore, if added on nickel foam (NF) or Ti-felt substrates, MXene functions as an electron bridge between these substrates and the electrocatalyst. For example, strong interactions with Ti3C2T x help to conduct the electrons effectively from NF to Ni2P nanoparticles, thus lowering the overpotential by 65 mV from Ni2P/NF to Ni2P/Ti3C2T x /NF [303]. The enhancement of electron conduction is influenced by factors such as the metallicity of the MXene, interactions between the MXene and the catalyst, as well as the presence of additional impurities or dopants. 9.4 Strain driving mechanism MXene characteristics and HER qualities may be tailored by creating flaws on the basal planes or edges to encourage various strain-driving systems. Strain may be caused by removing particular atoms from MXene, or active edge flaws can change the electronic structure, availability of active sites, adsorption energy for intermediates, and HER performance [304]. Gan et al. inspected the effects of M and C vacancies of M2CO2, where M represents different metal elements [305]. Introducing C or M, or C + M vacancies tunes H-adsorption energy. For instance, double C vacancies weaken the otherwise strong binding to H for V2CO2. Both C and Zr vacancies strengthened the binding of Zr2CO2. Change in these binding energies caused by vacancies is correlated to the change in the Fermi level of surface O, which would shift to either the conduction or valence band. The concentration of the vacancies affects the ΔG H. Yuwen et al. determined that the H-binding of Cr2CO2 is stronger with more C vacancies under similar H% coverage, which influences HER activity [306]. Fig. 15 (a) shows the change in the ΔG H at different levels of C vacancies in Cr2CO2 (denoted as Vc-Cr2CO2) defects at changing H% coverage, where at less than 25% C vacancies, the ΔG H may be adjusted closer to zero. On the other hand, converting 2D MXenes into 1D or 0D structures will create active edge defects that offer more available catalytic active sites. Jiang et al. showed that 0D Ti3C2 quantum dots formed from Li intercalation of 2D Ti3C2 enhanced the HER performance by 13.7 times [307]. It was attributed to the more moderate binding energies of the metal atoms at the edge sites and, therefore, the greater HER kinetics at these sites. Hence, controlling these defects can be one of the strategies to optimize the HER activity of MXenes. A volcano curve is calculated and provided in Fig. 15(b) to examine further and compare the HER performance of the aforementioned TM-Cr2CO2 MXenes [306]. Hao et al. ran AIMD (ab initio molecular dynamics) simulations for 4 ps as well as 8 ps to examine the durability of the TM-modified Cr2CO2 layer at 300 K and high temperature (500 K) [306]. Fig. 15(c–f) depicts the results of these simulations. Surprisingly, no structural rebuilding was detected in Ni-Cr2CO2 and Co-Cr2CO2 at 300 K during the 4 and 8 ps simulations. Furthermore, there was no difference in the structures of TM-Cr2CO2 between the 4 and 8 ps simulations. However, after raising the temperature to 500 K, that is substantially greater than the average working temperature of HER. These data clearly show that the structure of TM-Cr2CO2 is very stable even at the HER temperature. 9.5 External atom doping Doping with other elements introduces additional active sites into the MXene to facilitate HER kinetics. These dopants may be in the form of heteroatoms, non-metallic or metallic elements. Nitridation introduces the N heteroatoms on the surface of MXene that function as additional active sites for HER. It has been revealed that the N-doped Ti2CO2 achieved the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption is approaching 0 eV than the pristine Ti2CO2 [301]. Yoon et al. carried out the nitridation of Ti2CT x using NaNH2 to produce N-Ti2CT x [308]. The presence of Na allows the intercalation and delamination of Ti2CT x . N–Ti bonds were observed to form on the defects of Ti2CT x . N–O–Ti, pyridinic and graphitic N–C and pyridinic-N oxides are also present. HER overpotential of N-Ti2CT x is around 215 mV, while pristine Ti2CT x has negligible HER efficacy in 0.5 M H2SO4. The N groups not only contribute to the increase in electrochemically active surface area but also better conductivity from the Ti–N bonds, and the delamination of Ti2CT x provided a higher surface area. N-groups can also be incorporated into MXene through careful calcination in the presence of ammonia. Le et al. [309] determined that the N-doped Ti3C2T x prepared by annealing at 600 °C with ammonia showed the lowest overpotential value of 198 mV at a current density of 10 mA/cm2 in 0.5 M H2SO4. It was suggested that O–Ti–N and N–H groups take part in the HER electrocatalytic activity to boost the reaction. Annealing at 600 °C resulted in high concentrations of O–Ti–N and N–H groups. However, the increasing number of active sites did not contribute to the improved HER. Appropriate content of N groups increases the otherwise very negative ΔG H of Ti3C2T x . These N groups refer to those that are terminated on the Ti3C2T x as well as those that substituted the C atoms. Furthermore, delaminated N-Ti3C2T x offers a more exposed electrochemically active surface area that facilitates the transfer of ions/charge. Besides nitridation, phosphorization provides an opportunity to introduce P-groups onto the MXene surface. Qu et al. carried out phosphorization of Mo2CT x to synthesize P-Mo2CT x , wherein Mo–P bonds were detected along with elevated oxygen content [310]. Incorporating –P and –O functional groups served as supplementary active sites and facilitated electron conductivity, thereby reducing overpotential from 300 to 186 mV at 10 mA/cm2 in a 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte. Electronic properties and HER activity on MXene are also altered by metal atom doping or with single-atom catalysts (SACs). MXenes are excellent support for SACs with excellent electrocatalytic activity within their atomic size [311]. There are various SACs studied with different types of MXene. Zhang et al. studied the effect of adsorbed metal atoms such as Ni, Fe, Co as well as Cu on O-terminated Cr2CO2 and Cr2TiC2O2 towards HER [312]. It was suggested that increased electron charge on –O upon adsorption of the metal atoms on the surface of MXenes contributes to enhanced HER by weakening the H-adsorption strength. Zhe et al. demonstrated that Cu, Ag, and W SACs bonded to –O in Ti2CO2 effectively modified the Gibbs free energy to a level close to the optimum, thus enhancing the HER activity in acidic electrolytes [313]. These findings highlight the beneficial effects of introducing heteroatoms or metal dopants in MXene structures for improved HER performance. 9.6 Synergetic composites Aside from doping with single atoms, MXenes effectively function as co-catalysts or supports for HER catalytic components. Synergistically hybridizing or coupling MXenes with various HER nanocatalysts leads to more favourable HER kinetics along with better durability, such as the more stable PtNi supported on Ti3C2. Yan et al. revealed that PtNi octahedron on Ti3C2 retained about 92% of current density over 24 h in alkaline and a small overpotential increase of about 4 mV after repeated CV cycling tests, better than unsupported PtNi [314]. Uniform lattice strain distribution and interfacial interaction between PtNi and Ti3C2 contributed to enhanced durability and HER activity. Even with modifications to the morphology of MXene, it does not change its role as co-catalyst/support. Kang et al. fabricated holey porous Ti3C2T x through a chemical method involving oxidation with H2O2 [315]. NiCoP supported on the porous Ti3C2T x showed 63 mV lower overpotential than unsupported NiCoP in 0.5 M H2SO4. The porosity of the holey Ti3C2T x enlarged the surface area, easing the access of electrolytes to active sites. HER kinetics of NiCoP was improved owing to the fast electron conduction of Ti3C2T x . Further, it is also possible to assemble MXene nanosheets into a 3D porous structure. Nanosheets can be combined with other 2D nanomaterials. Yang et al. constructed a unique 3D porous structure by combining Ti3C2T x nanosheets with g-C3N4 and graphene [3]. Synergistic effects provide more active sites while maintaining sufficient electron conductivity. The triple component composite showed 38 mV onset overpotential in 0.5 M H2SO4, much lower than that of individual components and binary composites. Therefore, the various means of modifying MXenes and hybridizing MXenes with other HER-active materials make MXene more favourable for HER with enhanced durability. Effects of the MXene towards its supporting material depend on the properties of the MXene itself. Hence, a deep understanding of the role of different transition metals, termination groups, presence of dopants, and defects on the MXene towards HER is important. Fabricating composites with MXene requires careful optimization of each parameter during synthesis to yield the desired improvement in HER properties. However, the properties of MXenes are adjustable to achieve the desirable HER kinetics, improve H-adsorption, and lower the overpotential in acidic or alkaline electrolytes. Thinner layers of MXenes offer more exposed active sites and easier electrolyte access. In addition, Termination groups are important to bind with the hydrogen intermediates. It should be considered that the effects of termination groups towards HER activity vary with the type of MXene. Other modifications such as doping with heteroatoms, non-metal or metal elements, available defect sites, and creating HER composites of MXene with other HER-active components can modify the electronic structure as well as optimise the H-adsorption energies. These approaches potentially lead to enhanced electrocatalytic HER activity of the MXenes, where all aspects of the MXenes are considered. 10 Challenges and opportunities 10.1 Existing challenges for MXene-based electrocatalysts The initial obstacle when selecting an electrocatalyst based on MXene is its structural stability. The deterioration in MXenes in electrocatalysis offers two key issues. First, changes in MXene chemistry and physical characteristics may gradually decline catalytic activity, thereby limiting the practical uses of materials. Second, the breakdown of the MXene may result in the production of alternative active sites, resulting in an improperly ascribed active site in the original MXene, impeding future studies and comprehension of MXene electrocatalysts [158]. Consequently, enhancing the stability of MXene surfaces may be achieved by applying a layer resistant to oxidation [316]. The attainment of the desired surface chemistry as well as composition for electrocatalysts based on MXene poses a significant technological constraint [317]. The precise manipulation of surface terminations, such as introducing or removing –OH or –F groups, is crucial for correctly adjusting their catalytic activity in water splitting, including the HER [318]. Therefore, investigating the appropriate synthesis process may help to reduce the discrepancy between theoretical predictions and currently available experimental evidence [61]. Furthermore, it has been shown that MXenes are susceptible to deterioration when exposed to acidic or alkaline conditions, which significantly challenge their overall stability in electrocatalytic systems that are intended for long-term use (more than 100 h). In order to address the challenges associated with MXene stacking, researchers have employed different strategies. These include creating composite structures, such as rGO/MXene composites [319,320], developing 3D architectures like aerogels and foams [321], and incorporating the transition metal sulfide and hybrid bimetallic phosphonate as electrocatalyst [255]. The use of spacing agents, such as interlayer spacers or intercalants, and defect and interface engineering has also been explored [322,323]. By considering the synthesis and modification procedures described above, the hydrogen generation efficiency of MXenes-based electrocatalysts may be increased in the near future in the following ways (the schematic illustration is shown in Fig. 16 ). (a) Synthesis and modification. The low production yield of MXenes provides considerable difficulty for large-scale manufacture. Researchers have made noteworthy efforts to solve this problem. For instance, Eom et al. developed a wet-spinning assembly process to directly and continuously produce 1D MXene fibres [324]. This novel approach has the potential for continuous as well as large-scale manufacturing, and the resultant 1D fibres have an extraordinary electrical conductivity of 7713 S cm−1. The newly discovered Mo4VAlC4 MAX phase [325], as well as its related Mo4VC4 MXenes, have opened the door to the laboratory synthesis of a wide range of novel MXenes. These novel MXenes, composed of five or more transition metal atomic layers, have a high potential for future performance in the area of HER. Mo5C4 and Mo4TiC4 are two examples of potential MXenes. Furthermore, new discoveries on chemically ordered W-based (W2/3R1/3)2AlC MAX phases, including different elements (R = Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, and Lu), have opened the road for the development of 2D W1.33C MXene derivatives. Enhancing the HER activity of MXenes, derived from etching various MAX phases, is achievable by exploring and incorporating additional components into the M, A, and X layers [6]. This can be done under different conditions, such as varying the pH of the etching solution, adjusting the etching time, selecting specific solvents and intercalators, and employing distinct methods for additional treatment. These strategic interventions aim to yield MXenes with tailored properties and a high overall yield. (b) Modified MAX phase synthesis. Given that the presence of inadequate etching and a minor flaw of remaining A atoms during the MAX etching process can improve the HER activity of MXenes, it is possible to enhance the HER performance of MXenes obtained through MAX etching by introducing specific compounds during their synthesis. These compounds may have an excess of the transition metal M, a surplus of A atoms, or a surplus of C, N, or CN. These compounds such as Mo-(Mo4AlC3), W-(W3AlC2), Al-(Mo4AlC3), Zn-(V4ZnC3), C-(W4AlC3), N-(Ti2AlN), and CN– are examples of such compounds (Ti3AlCN) can be added to MXenes to improve their HER performance. While the inclusion of inner layer elements can decrease the formation energy of MXenes, the electron properties of ordered double transition metal MXenes are directly influenced by the outer layer transition metal. Alternatively, these outer layer elements can effectively bridge the gap observed in studying single transition metal MXenes, thereby broadening the spectrum of electrocatalysts. (c) Utilization of in situ techniques. According to research [319,326], the electrochemical procedure may drastically modify the surface composition of active catalytic species. This behaviour is most noticeable in metal carbides and nitrides, which often undergo conversions at varying pH levels and applied potentials. As a result, the ex-situ characterizations of the oxidation states and stoichiometries of MXene-based catalysts may vary from their real states during the process. To precisely examine the chemical and structural attributes of supported catalysts under legitimate electrocatalytic conditions, it is vital to use in situ methods such as environmental transmission electron microscopy (TEM) as well as synchrotron-based X-ray diffraction and X-ray absorption methods. These approaches allow for the analysis of the features of the catalysts while they are exposed to the particular circumstances of the electrochemical reaction [327]. (d) Improvement of electrocatalytic selectivity. MXene catalysts are often more efficient in electrochemical processes with fewer proton/electron transfer steps, leading to enhanced HER performance [6]. HER electrocatalysis with MXenes is mainly based on the deep knowledge of their compositing effects and intrinsic electronic properties. The surface functional groups and composition both influence the electronic properties of MXenes. As heteroatoms or transition metals are modified the MXens, the electronic properties of MXenes can be magnificently modified via their composition [327]. It should be noted that HER competes with other processes such as OER, ORR, N2RR, and CO2RR [328,329]. To achieve selectivity in product synthesis, important intermediates must be stabilized by partnership with other active catalytic species. MXenes, for example, have shown the potential to enable HER with only three electron transfer steps. As a result, future efforts should focus on mixing MXenes with other active ingredients to maximize synergistic effects as well as improve overall performance [327]. 11 Summary and outlook Emerging PGM-free catalysts in the form of 2D nanomaterials, such as TMDs, TMCs, TMOs, TMNs, TMPs, and TMSs, have exhibited great potential as electrochemical catalysts for HER. Furthermore, MXenes, with rich surface chemistry, hydrophilicity, and excellent electrical conductivity, can be a perfect constituent for preparing nanohybrid or heterostructures. MXenes-based heterostructures synergistically influence both the electrochemical activity and structural stability of the system. Whereas, in MXenes-supported nanohybrids, the MXenes continue a robust substrate to support the stability of the electrocatalytic system and substantial donor to electron conduction. The MXene family abundance has allowed researchers to use them as optional loading materials and substrates, where the MXene presence plays a crucial role in preventing aggregation problems and minimizing catalytic deactivation. To determine the ideal substrate/loadings ratio, the interaction mode and position between the MXenes and loadings must be thoroughly investigated during the experimental procedure. Notably, 2D MXenes have garnered significant attention among these materials due to their cutting-edge nature and exceptional qualities. In the field of energy storage and conversion, the dominance of the 2D MXene structure, characterized by a larger number of exposed active sites and a remarkably short diffusion path, results in excellent catalytic performance comparable to that of Pt catalysts. Moreover, the atomic thickness and chemical accessibility of 2D MXenes nanoparticles allow for various modification techniques to enhance their catalytic activity. Current research in this area focuses on two main aspects. Firstly, efforts are being made to engineer the structure of MXenes by reducing the number of layers to expose more active sites. Secondly, edge and defect engineering approaches are being explored to create additional active sites. Additionally, strain engineering, heteroatom doping, and developing synergetic composites are investigated to improve the charge transfer kinetics, thereby accelerating the electrochemical reactions. Certain metallic 2D catalysts also possess intrinsic advantages for HER catalysis, as their basal plane can exhibit catalytic activity in addition to the active edges. Researchers must consider both the active sites and electron transport properties in pursuing high-performance HER catalysts. Despite significant progress in these areas, developing more competitive catalysts is still necessary. Furthermore, as HER electrocatalysts are prone to corrosion during electrolysis, further research is required to develop robust catalysts. The mechanisms underlying the HER performance of these 2D MXenes catalyst families are currently unknown and demand further investigation. We believe that studying catalysts based on MXenes will not only advance theoretical research but also facilitate their practical applications. coredata.dc:description: The increasing focus on electrocatalysis for sustainable hydrogen (H2) production has prompted significant interest in MXenes, a class of two-dimensional (2D) materials comprising metal carbides, carbonitrides, and nitrides. These materials exhibit intriguing chemical and physical properties, including excellent electrical conductivity and a large surface area, making them attractive candidates for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). This scientific review explores recent advancements in MXene-based electrocatalysts for HER kinetics. It discusses various compositions, functionalities, and explicit design principles while providing a comprehensive overview of synthesis methods, exceptional properties, and electro-catalytic approaches for H2 production via electrochemical reactions. Furthermore, challenges and future prospects in designing MXenes-based electrocatalysts with enhanced kinetics are highlighted, emphasizing the potential of incorporating different metals to expand the scope of electrochemical reactions. This review suggests possible efforts for developing advanced MXenes-based electrocatalysts, particularly for efficient H2 generation through electrochemical water-splitting reactions..

coredata.dc:title: MXenes and heterostructures-based electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction: Recent developments and future outlook
